channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Elon Musk Takes Twitter, and Tech Deals, to Another Level
item.description: Silicon Valley moguls used to buy yachts and islands. Now they are rich enough, and perhaps arrogant enough, to acquire companies they fancy.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld

item.title: Elon Owns Twitter + Apple’s Developer Tax + Meta’s Dismal Earning Report
item.description: The world’s richest man just closed the deal, promising that the company won’t become a ‘hellscape’, appointing himself ‘Chief Twit’ and promptly firing top executives.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Jim Wilson/The New York Times

item.title: Twitter Employees Fear Elon Musk Won’t Make Promised Payouts
item.description: The social network’s new owner has just a few days to determine whether to pay millions to employees, or get rid of them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

item.title: Nancy Pelosi’s Husband, Paul Pelosi, Is Attacked in Their San Francisco Home
item.description: Paul Pelosi, 82, was hospitalized after the assault but was expected to recover, a spokesman for Ms. Pelosi said. The police said a suspect was in custody.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Paul Pelosi, the husband of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, in March.

item.title: Xi Jinping vs. the People
item.description: How Chinese citizens are responding to Xi’s lengthened rule.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Exxon and Chevron Rack Up Giant Profits
item.description: A fourth straight quarter of robust results came on the back of high oil and natural gas prices.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: An Exxon Mobil refinery in Baton Rouge, La.

item.title: With Recession Looming, Big European Economies Still Show Some Growth
item.description: Germany surprised economists by expanding in the third quarter, but the French and Spanish economies both slowed down.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers in Berlin. The German economy expanded slightly in the third quarter, partly thanks to consumer spending.

item.title: Coal Baron or Climate Warrior? The Dizzying Rise of Asia’s Richest Man.
item.description: The business decisions of Gautam Adani could go a long way in determining whether India helps the world avert a climate catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gautam Adani, chairman and founder of the Adani Group, a multinational company based in Ahmedabad, India.

item.title: The 2022 race for the House, in four districts, and four polls.
item.description: Swing-district polls by The New York Times and Siena College show how the midterm races are being shaped by larger, surprising forces, beyond the traditional red and blue divide.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Nate Cohn

item.title: How Talk Radio Unites Ron Johnson and His Wisconsin Voters
item.description: The Republican senator from Wisconsin practically lives on talk radio, with hundreds of appearances in 2022. It keeps him in tune with base voters, and is helping him in his vital Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Talk radio is crucial to the conservative movement, because we don’t have the mainstream media on our side,” Senator Ron Johnson said in a recent interview.

item.title: With Majority in Sight, Republicans Hush Talk of Impeaching Biden
item.description: Party leaders have begun to equivocate about whether they would seek to impeach President Biden if they won a House majority, but pressure is building from those who have vowed to do so.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, has expressed a stance on impeaching President Biden that appears to be at odds with some of the members of his conference.

item.title: Elise Stefanik Believes She Can Turn New York Into a Republican State
item.description: Ms. Stefanik, who leads the House Republican Conference, represents a hard right turn from New York’s tradition of so-called Rockefeller Republicanism.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Elise Stefanik predicts that the Republican Party will win a majority of New York’s 26 House seats in November.

item.title: Ksenia Sobchak, a Kremlin Critic, Leaves Russia
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak entered Lithuania this week.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak with President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin in 2018, a day after he won the presidential election, in which she had also been a candidate.

item.title: Many UFO Reports Are Just Spy Drones or Airborne Trash
item.description: Forget space aliens or hypersonic technology; classified assessments show that many episodes have ordinary explanations.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Department of Defense, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A video image by Navy pilots of an “unidentified aerial phenomena.”

item.title: Most NYC Job Postings Must Include Salaries Starting in November
item.description: A new city law going into effect on Tuesday will require companies with at least four employees to post salary ranges for openings, even if the jobs involve remote or hybrid work.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:description: Starting in November a new law in New York City will require job postings in the city to include a salary range.

item.title: For Rishi Sunak, Family Wealth From Outsourcing Adds to a Secretive Fortune
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister married into an $800 million stake in Infosys, a company that does not fit neatly into his party’s views on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Mark Cuthbert/UK Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, during a reception to celebrate the British Asian Trust at the British Museum in February.

item.title: World Series Preview: Philadelphia Has an Edge on Houston
item.description: For a city that rarely reaches the top, Philadelphia has a strange pattern of success against Houston. The Astros will try to overcome that in the World Series against the Phillies.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Brett Coomer/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Philadelphia’s strange run of sports success against Houston includes the Phillies clinching a playoff berth with a win over the Astros on Oct. 3.

item.title: World Series: Phillies’ Rhys Hoskins Perfects the Art of Getting Back Up
item.description: Bryce Harper calls him Captain and Dave Dombrowski says he “epitomizes” the club. Rhys Hoskins is mostly concerned with this Phillies team writing its own story.
item.dc:creator: Scott Miller

item.title: The Rising Tide of Global Sadness
item.description: The anger and sadness in culture seem to reflect people’s growing disappointment with their lives.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.category: Blind Spot: The Global Rise of Unhappiness and How Leaders Missed It (Book)

item.title: Elon Musk Is Buying Twitter. Shudder.
item.description: Rogue billionaires have appeared before, and they will appear again. But this one will control our “digital town square.”
item.dc:creator: David Nasaw

item.title: On Affirmative Action, What Once Seemed Unthinkable Might Become Real
item.description: Should diversity still be considered the compelling interest in college admissions that the court said it was in 1978?
item.dc:creator: Linda Greenhouse
item.category: Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: Two Futures Face Off in Brazil
item.description: The fate of democracy is at stake in the nation’s most important election in decades.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Rachelle Bonja, Eric Krupke, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Chow, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters in Brazil on Sunday will choose between two candidates who have very different visions for the country.

item.title: A Zuni Café Classic Without the Chicken? It’s Possible.
item.description: Try a warm bread salad with crisp mushrooms, inspired by the restaurant dish.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao

item.title: ‘No Jobs Available’: The Feast or Famine Careers of America’s Port Drivers.
item.description: Consumer demand has cooled, leaving fewer containers to pick up on the West Coast. For Marshawn Jackson, a truck driver paid by the delivery, that means a hard scrabble to make ends meet.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Brandon Pavan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Jackson with his truck in a parking lot in Ontario, Calif.

item.title: Win or Lose, Bolsonaro Has Destroyed Trust in Brazil’s Elections
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro has attacked Brazil’s electronic voting system. Now, ahead of Sunday’s elections, many of his supporters believe there will be fraud.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Bolsonaro’s supporters focus their attention on a series of anecdotal apparent abnormalities in the voting process and results, as well as many conspiracy theories.

item.title: A Fire, an Arrest and a New Challenge for the Federal Burn Program
item.description: U.S. Forest Service officials decried the arrest of an employee who was leading prescribed burns in Oregon, where residents accused the agency of reckless burning.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: Smoke from a prescribed burn loomed over cattle belonging to the Holliday family near the town of John Day, Ore.

item.title: Somalia Asks U.S. to Step Up Drone Strikes Against Qaeda-Linked Fighters
item.description: A new administration in Somalia has launched an offensive against Al Shabab, which are also facing an uprising from local militias.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Shabab fighters outside Mogadishu, Somalia, in 2008. The Somali government wants U.S. military operators to be able to attack groups of Shabab militants who might pose a threat to Somali forces.

item.title: How to Help Someone With Depression
item.description: Whether they are coping with seasonal symptoms or chronic depression, here’s how to offer love and understanding while still caring for yourself.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón

item.title: Terrence Real’s Latest Book Explores Fixing What Ails Us
item.description: In his new book, ‘Us’, Terrence Real explores how ‘enlightened self interest’ could save your relationship.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Jones

item.title: How Online Dating Apps Can Lead to Burnout
item.description: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Book Review: ‘Ted Kennedy,’ by John A. Farrell
item.description: John A. Farrell’s “Ted Kennedy” is a sympathetic take on a complex life.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Mallon

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
